015/**
016 * 64-bit and 32-bit hashing functions that we can rely on staying the same cross-platform.
017 * Several algorithms are present here, each with some tradeoffs for performance, quality,
018 * and extra features. Each algorithm was designed for speed and general-purpose usability,
019 * but not cryptographic security.
020 * <br>
021 * The hashes this returns are always 0 when given null to hash. Arrays with
022 * identical elements of identical types will hash identically. Arrays with identical
023 * numerical values but different types will sometimes hash differently. This class
024 * always provides 64-bit hashes via hash64() and 32-bit hashes via hash(), and Wisp
025 * provides a hash32() method that matches older behavior and uses only 32-bit math.
026 * The hash64() and hash() methods, except in Hive, use 64-bit math even when producing
027 * 32-bit hashes, for GWT reasons. GWT doesn't have the same behavior as desktop and
028 * Android applications when using ints because it treats doubles mostly like ints,
029 * sometimes, due to it using JavaScript. If we use mainly longs, though, GWT emulates
030 * the longs with a more complex technique behind-the-scenes, that behaves the same on
031 * the web as it does on desktop or on a phone. Since CrossHash is supposed to be stable
032 * cross-platform, this is the way we need to go, despite it being slightly slower.
033 * <br>
034 * The static methods in CrossHash, like {@link #hash64(int[])}, delegate to the {@link Water}
035 * algorithm. This is a fairly fast and heavily-tested hash that developed from something like
036 * Wang Yi's wyhash algorithm, though only the constants and the general concept of a mum()
037 * function are shared with wyhash. There are several static inner classes in CrossHash
038 * {@link Water} (already mentioned), {@link Yolk} (which is very close to Water but allows a
039 * 64-bit salt or seed), {@link Curlup} (which is the fastest hash here for larger inputs, and
040 * also allows a 64-bit seed), {@link Mist} (which allows a 128-bit salt, but has mediocre
041 * quality), {@link Hive} (which is mostly here for compatibility, but has OK quality and good
042 * collision rates), and {@link Wisp} (which is fast for small inputs but has bad collision
043 * rates). There's also the inner IHasher interface, and the classes that implement it.
044 * Water, Yolk, and Curlup all pass the rigorous SMHasher test battery. The others don't pass
045 * it in full, or sometimes at all.
046 * <br>
047 * IHasher values are provided as static fields, and use Water to hash a specific type or fall
048 * back to Object.hashCode if given an object with the wrong type. IHasher values are optional
049 * parts of OrderedMap, OrderedSet, Arrangement, and the various classes that use Arrangement
050 * like K2 and K2V1, and allow arrays to be used as keys in those collections while keeping
051 * hashing by value instead of the normal hashing by reference for arrays. You probably won't
052 * ever need to make a class that implements IHasher yourself; for some cases you may want to
053 * look at the {@link Hashers} class for additional functions.
054 * <br>
055 * Note: This class was formerly called StableHash, but since that refers to a specific
056 * category of hashing algorithm that this is not, and since the goal is to be cross-
057 * platform, the name was changed to CrossHash.
058 * Note 2: FNV-1a was removed from SquidLib on July 25, 2017, and replaced as default with Wisp; Wisp
059 * was later replaced as default by Hive, and in June 2019 Hive was replaced by Water. Wisp was used
060 * because at the time SquidLib preferred 64-bit math when math needed to be the same across platforms;
061 * math on longs behaves the same on GWT as on desktop, despite being slower. Hive passed an older version
062 * of SMHasher, a testing suite for hashes, where Wisp does not (it fails just like Arrays.hashCode()
063 * does). Hive uses a cross-platform subset of the possible 32-bit math operations when producing 32-bit 
064 * hashes of data that doesn't involve longs or doubles, and this should speed up the CrossHash.Hive.hash()
065 * methods a lot on GWT, but it slows down 32-bit output on desktop-class JVMs. Water became the default
066 * when newer versions of SMHasher showed that Hive wasn't as high-quality as it had appeared, and the
067 * recently-debuted wyhash by Wang Yi, a variation on a hash called MUM, opened some possibilities for
068 * structures that are simple but also very fast. Water is modeled after wyhash and uses the same constants
069 * in its hash64() methods, but avoids the 128-bit multiplication that wyhash uses. Because both wyhash and
070 * Water operate on 4 items at a time, they tend to be very fast on desktop platforms, but Water probably
071 * won't be amazing at GWT performance. Similarly, the recently-added Curlup performs very well due to SIMD
072 * optimizations that HotSpot performs, and probably won't do as well on GWT or Android.
073 * <br>
074 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 1/16/2016.
075 * @author Tommy Ettinger
076 */
077public class CrossHash {

272    /**
273     * An interface that can be used to move the logic for the hashCode() and equals() methods from a class' methods to
274     * an implementation of IHasher that certain collections in SquidLib can use. Primarily useful when the key type is
275     * an array, which normally doesn't work as expected in Java hash-based collections, but can if the right collection
276     * and IHasher are used. See also {@link Hashers} for additional implementations, some of which need dependencies on
277     * things the rest of CrossHash doesn't, like a case-insensitive String hasher/equator that uses RegExodus to handle
278     * CharSequence comparison on GWT.
279     */
280    public interface IHasher extends Serializable {
281        /**
282         * If data is a type that this IHasher can specifically hash, this method should use that specific hash; in
283         * other situations, it should simply delegate to calling {@link Object#hashCode()} on data. The body of an
284         * implementation of this method can be very small; for an IHasher that is meant for byte arrays, the body could
285         * be: {@code return (data instanceof byte[]) ? CrossHash.Lightning.hash((byte[]) data) : data.hashCode();}
286         *
287         * @param data the Object to hash; this method should take any type but often has special behavior for one type
288         * @return a 32-bit int hash code of data
289         */
290        int hash(final Object data);
291
292        /**
293         * Not all types you might want to use an IHasher on meaningfully implement .equals(), such as array types; in
294         * these situations the areEqual method helps quickly check for equality by potentially having special logic for
295         * the type this is meant to check. The body of implementations for this method can be fairly small; for byte
296         * arrays, it looks like: {@code return left == right
297         * || ((left instanceof byte[] && right instanceof byte[])
298         * ? Arrays.equals((byte[]) left, (byte[]) right)
299         * : Objects.equals(left, right));} , but for multidimensional arrays you should use the
300         * {@link #equalityHelper(Object[], Object[], IHasher)} method with an IHasher for the inner arrays that are 1D
301         * or otherwise already-hash-able, as can be seen in the body of the implementation for 2D char arrays, where
302         * charHasher is an existing IHasher that handles 1D arrays:
303         * {@code return left == right
304         * || ((left instanceof char[][] && right instanceof char[][])
305         * ? equalityHelper((char[][]) left, (char[][]) right, charHasher)
306         * : Objects.equals(left, right));}
307         *
308         * @param left  allowed to be null; most implementations will have special behavior for one type
309         * @param right allowed to be null; most implementations will have special behavior for one type
310         * @return true if left is equal to right (preferably by value, but reference equality may sometimes be needed)
311         */
312        boolean areEqual(final Object left, final Object right);
313    }
314
315    /**
316     * Not a general-purpose method; meant to ease implementation of {@link IHasher#areEqual(Object, Object)}
317     * methods when the type being compared is a multi-dimensional array (which normally requires the heavyweight method
318     * {@link Arrays#deepEquals(Object[], Object[])} or doing more work yourself; this reduces the work needed to
319     * implement fixed-depth equality). As mentioned in the docs for {@link IHasher#areEqual(Object, Object)}, example
320     * code that hashes 2D char arrays can be done using an IHasher for 1D char arrays called charHasher:
321     * {@code return left == right
322     * || ((left instanceof char[][] && right instanceof char[][])
323     * ? equalityHelper((char[][]) left, (char[][]) right, charHasher)
324     * : Objects.equals(left, right));}
325     *
326     * @param left an array of some kind of Object, usually an array, that the given IHasher can compare
327     * @param right an array of some kind of Object, usually an array, that the given IHasher can compare
328     * @param inner an IHasher to compare items in left with items in right
329     * @return true if the contents of left and right are equal by the given IHasher, otherwise false
330     */
331    public static boolean equalityHelper(Object[] left, Object[] right, IHasher inner) {
332        if (left == right)
333            return true;
334        if (left == null || right == null || left.length != right.length)
335            return false;
336        for (int i = 0; i < left.length; i++) {
337            if (!inner.areEqual(left[i], right[i]))
338                return false;
339        }
340        return true;
341    }
342
343    private static class BooleanHasher implements IHasher, Serializable {
344        private static final long serialVersionUID = 3L;
345
346        BooleanHasher() {
347        }
348
349        @Override
350        public int hash(final Object data) {
351            return (data instanceof boolean[]) ? CrossHash.hash((boolean[]) data) : data.hashCode();
352        }
353
354        @Override
355        public boolean areEqual(Object left, Object right) {
356            return left == right || ((left instanceof boolean[] && right instanceof boolean[]) ? Arrays.equals((boolean[]) left, (boolean[]) right) : Objects.equals(left, right));
357        }
358    }
359
360    public static final IHasher booleanHasher = new BooleanHasher();
361
362    private static class ByteHasher implements IHasher, Serializable {
363        private static final long serialVersionUID = 3L;
364
365        ByteHasher() {
366        }
367
368        @Override
369        public int hash(final Object data) {
370            return (data instanceof byte[]) ? CrossHash.hash((byte[]) data) : data.hashCode();
371        }
372
373        @Override
374        public boolean areEqual(Object left, Object right) {
375            return left == right
376                    || ((left instanceof byte[] && right instanceof byte[])
377                    ? Arrays.equals((byte[]) left, (byte[]) right)
378                    : Objects.equals(left, right));
379        }
380    }

498    private static class Char2DHasher implements IHasher, Serializable {
499        private static final long serialVersionUID = 3L;
500
501        Char2DHasher() {
502        }
503
504        @Override
505        public int hash(final Object data) {
506            return (data instanceof char[][]) ? CrossHash.hash((char[][]) data) : data.hashCode();
507        }
508
509        @Override
510        public boolean areEqual(Object left, Object right) {
511            return left == right
512                    || ((left instanceof char[][] && right instanceof char[][])
513                    ? equalityHelper((char[][]) left, (char[][]) right, charHasher)
514                    : Objects.equals(left, right));
515        }
516    }

623    private static class DefaultHasher implements IHasher, Serializable {
624        private static final long serialVersionUID = 5L;
625
626        DefaultHasher() {
627        }
628
629        @Override
630        public int hash(final Object data) {
631            if(data == null) return 0;
632            final int x = data.hashCode() * 0x9E375;
633            return x ^ x >>> 16;
634        }
635
636        @Override
637        public boolean areEqual(final Object left, final Object right) {
638            return (left == right) || (left != null && left.equals(right));
639        }
640    }
641
642    public static final IHasher defaultHasher = new DefaultHasher();
643
644    private static class MildHasher implements IHasher, Serializable {
645        private static final long serialVersionUID = 4L;
646
647        MildHasher() {
648        }
649
650        @Override
651        public int hash(final Object data) {
652            return data != null ? data.hashCode() : 0;
653        }
654
655        @Override
656        public boolean areEqual(final Object left, final Object right) {
657            return (left == right) || (left != null && left.equals(right));
658        }
659    }
660
661    /**
662     * The most basic IHasher type; effectively delegates to {@link Objects#hashCode(Object)} and
663     * {@link Objects#equals(Object, Object)}. Might not scramble the bits of a hash well enough to have good
664     * performance in a hash table lke {@link OrderedMap} or {@link UnorderedSet}, unless the objects being hashed have
665     * good hashCode() implementations already.
666     */
667    public static final IHasher mildHasher = new MildHasher();
668
669    private static class IdentityHasher implements IHasher, Serializable
670    {
671        private static final long serialVersionUID = 4L;
672        IdentityHasher() { }
673
674        @Override
675        public int hash(Object data) {
676            return System.identityHashCode(data);
677        }
678
679        @Override
680        public boolean areEqual(Object left, Object right) {
681            return left == right;
682        }
683    }
684    public static final IHasher identityHasher = new IdentityHasher();
685
686    private static class GeneralHasher implements IHasher, Serializable {
687        private static final long serialVersionUID = 3L;
688
689        GeneralHasher() {
690        }
691
692        @Override
693        public int hash(final Object data) {
694            return CrossHash.hash(data);
695        }
696
697        @Override
698        public boolean areEqual(Object left, Object right) {
699            if(left == right) return true;
700            Class<?> l = left.getClass(), r = right.getClass();
701            if(l == r)
702            {
703                if(l.isArray())
704                {
705                    if(left instanceof int[]) return Arrays.equals((int[]) left, (int[]) right);
706                    else if(left instanceof long[]) return Arrays.equals((long[]) left, (long[]) right);
707                    else if(left instanceof char[]) return Arrays.equals((char[]) left, (char[]) right);
708                    else if(left instanceof double[]) return Arrays.equals((double[]) left, (double[]) right);
709                    else if(left instanceof boolean[]) return Arrays.equals((boolean[]) left, (boolean[]) right);
710                    else if(left instanceof byte[]) return Arrays.equals((byte[]) left, (byte[]) right);
711                    else if(left instanceof float[]) return Arrays.equals((float[]) left, (float[]) right);
712                    else if(left instanceof short[]) return Arrays.equals((short[]) left, (short[]) right);
713                    else if(left instanceof char[][]) return equalityHelper((char[][]) left, (char[][]) right, charHasher);
714                    else if(left instanceof int[][]) return equalityHelper((int[][]) left, (int[][]) right, intHasher);
715                    else if(left instanceof long[][]) return equalityHelper((long[][]) left, (long[][]) right, longHasher);
716                    else if(left instanceof CharSequence[]) return equalityHelper((CharSequence[]) left, (CharSequence[]) right, stringHasher);
717                    else if(left instanceof Object[]) return Arrays.equals((Object[]) left, (Object[]) right);
718                }
719                return Objects.equals(left, right);
720            }
721            return false;
722        }
723    }
724
725    /**
726     * This IHasher is the one you should use if you aren't totally certain what types will go in an OrderedMap's keys
727     * or an OrderedSet's items, since it can handle mixes of elements.
728     */
729    public static final IHasher generalHasher = new GeneralHasher();
730
731    /**
732     * A quick, simple hashing function that seems to have good results. Like LightRNG, it stores a state that
733     * it updates independently of the output, and this starts at a large prime. At each step, it takes the
734     * current item in the array being hashed, adds a large non-prime used in LightRNG's generation function
735     * (it's 2 to the 64, times the golden ratio phi, and truncated to a signed long), multiplies by a prime
736     * called the "state multiplier", adds the result to the state and stores it, multiplies the value of the
737     * state by another prime called the "output multiplier", then XORs the current result with that value
738     * before moving onto the next item in the array. A finalization step XORs the result with a complex value
739     * made by adding the state (left over from the previous step) to what was the output multiplier, adding
740     * the last known value for result to the phi-related constant from LightRNG, multiplying that pair, adding
741     * the initial state (which turns out to be unusually good for this, despite no particularly special numeric
742     * qualities other than being a probable prime) and then bitwise-rotating it left by a seemingly-random
743     * number drawn from the highest 6 bits of the state.
744     * <br>
745     * This all can be done very quickly; a million hashes of a million different 16-element long arrays can be
746     * computed in under 18-20 ms (in the benchmark, some amount of that is overhead from generating a new
747     * array with LongPeriodRNG, since the benchmark uses that RNG's state for data, and the default
748     * Arrays.hashCode implementation is only somewhat faster at under 16 ms). After several tries and tweaks
749     * to the constants this uses, it also gets remarkably few hash collisions. On the same 0x100000, or
750     * 1048576, RNG states for data, Lightning gets 110 collisions, the JDK Arrays.hashCode method gets 129
751     * collisions, Sip (implementing SipHash) gets 145 collisions, and CrossHash (using the FNV-1a algorithm)
752     * gets 135 collisions. Dispersion is not perfect, but
753     * at many bit sizes Lightning continues to have less collisions (it disperses better than the other hashes
754     * with several quantities of bits, at least on this test data). Lightning also does relatively well, though
755     * it isn't clearly ahead of the rest all the time, when hashing Strings, especially ones that use a larger
756     * set of letters, it seems (FakeLanguageGen was used to make test data, and languages that used more
757     * characters in their alphabet seemed to hash better with this than competing hashes for some reason).
758     * <br>
759     * There is certainly room for improvement with the specific numbers chosen; earlier versions used the
760     * state multiplier "Neely's number", which is a probable prime made by taking the radix-29 number
761     * "HARGNALLINSCLOPIOPEEPIO" (a reference to a very unusual TV show), truncating to 64 bits, and rotating
762     * right by 42 bits. This version uses "Neely's number" for an initial state and during finalization, and
763     * uses a different probable prime as the state multiplier, made with a similar process; it starts with the
764     * radix-36 number "EDSGERWDIJKSTRA", then does the same process but rotates right by 37 bits to obtain a
765     * different prime. This tweak seems to help with hash collisions. Extensive trial and error was used to
766     * find the current output multiplier, which has no real relationship to anything else but has exactly 32 of
767     * 64 bits set to 1, has 1 in the least and most significant bit indices (meaning it is negative and odd),
768     * and other than that seems to have better results on most inputs for mystifying reasons. Earlier versions
769     * applied a Gray code step to alter the output instead of a multiplier that heavily overflows to obfuscate
770     * state, but that had a predictable pattern for most of the inputs tried, which seemed less-than-ideal for
771     * a hash. Vitally, Lightning avoids predictable collisions that Arrays.hashCode has, like
772     * {@code Arrays.hashCode(new long[]{0})==Arrays.hashCode(new long[]{-1})}.
773     * <br>
774     * The output multiplier is 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L, the state multiplier is 0xD0E89D2D311E289FL, the number
775     * added to the state (from LightRNG and code derived from FastUtil, but obtained from the golden ratio
776     * phi) is 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L, and the starting state ("Neely's Number") is 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L.
777     * <br>
778     * To help find patterns in hash output in a visual way, you can hash an x,y point, take the bottom 24 bits,
779     * and use that as an RGB color for the pixel at that x,y point. On a 512x512 grid of points, the patterns
780     * in Arrays.hashCode and the default CrossHash algorithm (FNV-1a) are evident, and Sip (implementing
781     * SipHash) does approximately as well as Lightning, with no clear patterns visible (Sip has been removed
782     * from SquidLib because it needs a lot of code and is slower than Mist). The
783     * idea is from a technical report on visual uses for hashing,
784     * http://www.clockandflame.com/media/Goulburn06.pdf .
785     * <ul>
786     * <li>{@link java.util.Arrays#hashCode(int[])}: http://i.imgur.com/S4Gh1sX.png</li>
787     * <li>{@link CrossHash#hash(int[])}: http://i.imgur.com/x8SDqvL.png</li>
788     * <li>(Former) CrossHash.Sip.hash(int[]): http://i.imgur.com/keSpIwm.png</li>
789     * <li>{@link CrossHash.Lightning#hash(int[])}: http://i.imgur.com/afGJ9cA.png</li>
790     * </ul>
791     */
792    // tested output multipliers
793    // 0x DA1A459BD9B4C619L
794    // 0x DC1A459879B5C619L
795    // 0x DC1A479829B5E639L
796    // 0x DC1A479C29B5C639L
797    // 0x EA1C479692B5C639L
798    // 0x CA1C479692B5C635L // this gets 105 collisions, low
799    // 0x CABC479692B5C635L
800    // 0x DC1A479C29B5C647L
801    // 0x DC1A479C29B5C725L
802    // 0x CABC279692B5CB21L
803    // 0x C6BC279692B5CC83L // this gets 100 collisions, lowest
804    // 0x C6BC279692B4D8A5L
805    // 0x C6BC279692B4D345L
806    // 0x C6EC273692B4A4B9L
807    // 0x C6A3256B52D5B463L
808    // 0x C6A3256B52D5B463L
809    // 0x C6A3256D52D5B4C9L
810    // 0x D8A3256D52D5B619L
811    // 0x D96E6AC724658947L
812    // 0x D96E6AC724658C2DL
813    // 0x CCABF9E32FD684F9L
814    // 0x C314163FAF912A01L
815    // 0x C3246007A332C12AL
816    // 0x CA1C479692B5C6ABL
817    // 0x C6B5275692B5CC83 // untested so far
818    public static final class Lightning {

820        public static long hash64(final boolean[] data) {
821            if (data == null)
822                return 0;
823            long z = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, result = 1L;
824            for (int i = 0; i < data.length; i++) {
825                result ^= (z += (data[i] ? 0x9E3779B97F4A7C94L : 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xD0E89D2D311E289FL) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L;
826            }
827            return result ^ Long.rotateLeft((z * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L ^ result * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) + 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, (int) (z >>> 58));
828        }

900        /**
901         * Hashes only a subsection of the given data, starting at start (inclusive) and ending before end (exclusive).
902         *
903         * @param data  the char array to hash
904         * @param start the start of the section to hash (inclusive)
905         * @param end   the end of the section to hash (exclusive)
906         * @return a 64-bit hash code for the requested section of data
907         */
908        public static long hash64(final char[] data, final int start, final int end) {
909            if (data == null || start >= end)
910                return 0;
911            long z = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, result = 1L;
912            for (int i = start; i < end && i < data.length; i++) {
913                result ^= (z += (data[i] + 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xD0E89D2D311E289FL) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L;
914            }
915            return result ^ Long.rotateLeft((z * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L ^ result * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) + 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, (int) (z >>> 58));
916        }
917        /**
918         * Hashes only a subsection of the given data, starting at start (inclusive), ending before end (exclusive), and
919         * moving between chars in increments of step (which is always greater than 0).
920         *
921         * @param data  the char array to hash
922         * @param start the start of the section to hash (inclusive)
923         * @param end   the end of the section to hash (exclusive)
924         * @param step  how many elements to advance after using one element from data; must be greater than 0
925         * @return a 64-bit hash code for the requested section of data
926         */
927        public static long hash64(final char[] data, final int start, final int end, final int step) {
928            if (data == null || start >= end || step <= 0)
929                return 0;
930            long z = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, result = 1L;
931            for (int i = start; i < end && i < data.length; i += step) {
932                result ^= (z += (data[i] + 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xD0E89D2D311E289FL) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L;
933            }
934            return result ^ Long.rotateLeft((z * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L ^ result * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) + 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, (int) (z >>> 58));
935        }

945        }

997        public static long hash64(final Object[] data) {
998            if (data == null)
999                return 0;
1000            long z = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, result = 1L;
1001            Object o;
1002            for (int i = 0; i < data.length; i++) {
1003                o = data[i];
1004                result ^= (z += ((o == null ? 0 : o.hashCode()) + 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xD0E89D2D311E289FL) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L;
1005            }
1006            return result ^ Long.rotateLeft((z * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L ^ result * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) + 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, (int) (z >>> 58));
1007        }

1049        public static int hash(final int[] data) {

1055
1056            }
1057            return (int) ((result ^= Long.rotateLeft((z * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L ^ result * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) + 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, (int) (z >>> 58))) ^ (result >>> 32));

1090        /**
1091         * Hashes only a subsection of the given data, starting at start (inclusive) and ending before end (exclusive).
1092         *
1093         * @param data  the char array to hash
1094         * @param start the start of the section to hash (inclusive)
1095         * @param end   the end of the section to hash (exclusive)
1096         * @return a 32-bit hash code for the requested section of data
1097         */
1098        public static int hash(final char[] data, final int start, final int end) {
1099            if (data == null || start >= end)
1100                return 0;
1101
1102            long z = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, result = 1L;
1103            for (int i = start; i < end && i < data.length; i++) {
1104                result ^= (z += (data[i] + 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xD0E89D2D311E289FL) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L;
1105            }
1106            return (int) ((result ^= Long.rotateLeft((z * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L ^ result * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) + 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, (int) (z >>> 58))) ^ (result >>> 32));
1107        }
1108        /**
1109         * Hashes only a subsection of the given data, starting at start (inclusive), ending before end (exclusive), and
1110         * moving between chars in increments of step (which is always greater than 0).
1111         *
1112         * @param data  the char array to hash
1113         * @param start the start of the section to hash (inclusive)
1114         * @param end   the end of the section to hash (exclusive)
1115         * @param step  how many elements to advance after using one element from data; must be greater than 0
1116         * @return a 32-bit hash code for the requested section of data
1117         */
1118        public static int hash(final char[] data, final int start, final int end, final int step) {
1119            if (data == null || start >= end || step <= 0)
1120                return 0;
1121
1122            long z = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, result = 1L;
1123            for (int i = start; i < end && i < data.length; i += step) {
1124                result ^= (z += (data[i] + 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) * 0xD0E89D2D311E289FL) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L;
1125            }
1126            return (int) ((result ^= Long.rotateLeft((z * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L ^ result * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) + 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, (int) (z >>> 58))) ^ (result >>> 32));
1127        }

1197            }
1198            return (int) ((result ^= Long.rotateLeft((z * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L ^ result * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) + 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L, (int) (z >>> 58))) ^ (result >>> 32));

1201
1202    // Nice ints, all probable primes except the last one, for 32-bit hashing
1203    // 0x62E2AC0D 0x632BE5AB 0x85157AF5 0x9E3779B9
1204    /**
1205     * The fastest hash in CrossHash, with middling quality. Uses a finely-tuned mix of very few operations for each
1206     * element, plus a minimal and simple finalization step, and as such obtains superior speed on the standard
1207     * benchmark SquidLib uses for hashes (hashing one million 16-element long arrays, remaining the best in both 32-bit
1208     * and 64-bit versions). Specifically, Wisp takes 9.478 ms to generate a million 64-bit hashes on a recent laptop
1209     * with an i7-6700HQ processor (removing the time the control takes to generate the million arrays). For comparison,
1210     * the JDK's Arrays.hashCode method takes 13.642 ms on the same workload, though it produces 32-bit hashes. Wisp
1211     * performs almost exactly as well producing 32-bit hashes as it does 64-bit hashes, where Hive slows down
1212     * significantly on some input types. This also passes visual tests where an earlier version of Wisp did not.
1213     * Collision rates are slightly worse than other CrossHash classes, but are better than the JDK's
1214     * Arrays.hashCode method, that is, acceptably low when given varied-enough inputs. On certain kinds of similar
1215     * inputs, Wisp will struggle with a higher collision rate. For example, when hashing Strings that contain only
1216     * several spaces, then some combination of digits 0-5, then more spaces, Wisp does very badly, worse than
1217     * {@link String#hashCode()} (which also does badly, though not as badly), while other hashes here do fine (such as
1218     * Water, which is the default for {@link CrossHash#hash(CharSequence)}).
1219     * <br>
1220     * This version replaces an older version of Wisp that had serious quality issues and wasn't quite as fast. Since
1221     * the only reason one would use the older version was speed without regard for quality, and it was marked as Beta,
1222     * a faster version makes sense to replace the slower one, rather than add yet another nested class in CrossHash.
1223     * <br>
1224     * Wisp is no longer considered Beta-quality, but even though it is rather fast, it has some cases where categories
1225     * of input cause frequent collisions. {@link Water} is about 20% slower but doesn't have such categories of
1226     * pathologically bad inputs, and passes tests that Wisp fails badly on. Because the hash-based collections in
1227     * SquidLib need a pretty good hash function to work at their best (they use linear-probing with open addressing,
1228     * which struggles when hashes are bad), 20% loss of speed during hashing to avoid slower
1229     * lookups/insertions/deletions from {@link OrderedMap}, {@link OrderedSet}, {@link UnorderedMap},
1230     * {@link UnorderedSet}, {@link Arrangement}, and others is probably worth it; if you really need speed then you
1231     * should first consider {@link Curlup}, which is faster than Wisp on moderately-long input arrays (with 20 or more
1232     * items, usually), and only if you need a fast hash for small inputs, where collisions aren't a problem, should you
1233     * turn to Wisp.
1234     */
1235    public static final class Wisp {
1236        public static long hash64(final boolean[] data) {
1237            if (data == null)
1238                return 0;
1239            long result = 0x9E3779B97F4A7C94L, a = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L;
1240            final int len = data.length;
1241            for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
1242                result += (a ^= 0x8329C6EB9E6AD3E3L * (data[i] ? 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L : 0xAEF17502108EF2D9L));
1243            }
1244            return result * (a | 1L) ^ (result << 37 | result >>> 27);
1245        }

1362         * @return a 64-bit hash code for the requested section of data
1363         */
1364        public static long hash64(final char[] data, final int start, final int end, final int step) {

1368            final int len = Math.min(end, data.length);
1369            for (int i = start; i < len; i += step) {
1370                result += (a ^= 0x8329C6EB9E6AD3E3L * data[i]);
1371            }
1372            return result * (a | 1L) ^ (result << 37 | result >>> 27);

1585                result += (a ^= 0x85157AF5 * data[i]);
1586            }
1587            return result * (a | 1) ^ (result >>> 11 | result << 21);
1588        }

1801        /**
1802         * Hashes only a subsection of the given data, starting at start (inclusive), ending before end (exclusive), and
1803         * moving between chars in increments of step (which is always greater than 0).
1804         *
1805         * @param data  the char array to hash
1806         * @param start the start of the section to hash (inclusive)
1807         * @param end   the end of the section to hash (exclusive)
1808         * @param step  how many elements to advance after using one element from data; must be greater than 0
1809         * @return a 32-bit hash code for the requested section of data
1810         */
1811        public static int hash(final char[] data, final int start, final int end, final int step) {
1812            if (data == null || start >= end || step <= 0)
1813                return 0;
1814            long result = 0x9E3779B97F4A7C94L, a = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L;
1815            final int len = Math.min(end, data.length);
1816            for (int i = start; i < len; i+= step) {
1817                result += (a ^= 0x8329C6EB9E6AD3E3L * data[i]);
1818            }
1819            return (int)(result * (a | 1L) ^ (result << 37 | result >>> 27));
1820        }

1918
1919    /**
1920     * A whole cluster of Wisp-like hash functions that sacrifice a small degree of speed, but can be built with up
1921     * to 128 bits of salt values that help to obscure what hashing function is actually being used. This class is
1922     * similar to the older Storm variety, but is somewhat faster and has many more possible salt "states" when using
1923     * the constructors that take two longs or a CharSequence. There isn't really any reason to use Storm, so Mist has
1924     * now replaced Storm entirely. Code that used Storm should be able to just change any usage of "Storm" to "Mist",
1925     * or can instead use {@link Yolk} or {@link Curlup} for higher quality and speed but smaller salt size.
1926     * <br>
1927     * The salt fields are not serialized, so it is important that the same salt will be given by the
1928     * program when the same hash results are wanted for some inputs.
1929     * <br>
1930     * A group of 48 static, final, pre-initialized Mist members are present in this class, 24 with the
1931     * name of a letter in the Greek alphabet (this uses the convention on Wikipedia,
1932     * https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greek_alphabet#Letters , where lambda is spelled with a 'b') and 24 with the same
1933     * name followed by an underscore, such as {@link #alpha_}. The whole group of 48 pre-initialized members are also
1934     * present in a static array called {@code predefined}. These can be useful when, for example, you want to get
1935     * multiple hashes of a single array or String as part of cuckoo hashing or similar techniques that need multiple
1936     * hashes for the same inputs.
1937     */
1938    public static final class Mist implements Serializable {
1939        private static final long serialVersionUID = -1275284837479983271L;
1940
1941        private transient final long l1, l2;
1942
1943        public Mist() {
1944            this(0x1234567876543210L, 0xEDCBA98789ABCDEFL);
1945        }
1946
1947        public Mist(final CharSequence alteration) {
1948            this(CrossHash.hash64(alteration), Lightning.hash64(alteration));
1949        }
1950        private static int permute(final long state)
1951        {
1952            int s = (int)state ^ 0xD0E89D2D;
1953            s = (s >>> 19 | s << 13);
1954            s ^= state >>> (5 + (state >>> 59));
1955            return ((s *= 277803737) >>> 22) ^ s;
1956        }
1957
1958        @SuppressWarnings("NumericOverflow")
1959        public Mist(final long alteration) {
1960            long l1, l2;
1961            l1 = alteration + permute(alteration);
1962            l1 = (l1 ^ (l1 >>> 30)) * 0xBF58476D1CE4E5B9L;
1963            l1 = (l1 ^ (l1 >>> 27)) * 0x94D049BB133111EBL;
1964            this.l1 = l1 ^ l1 >>> 31;
1965
1966            l2 = alteration + 6 * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
1967            l2 = (l2 ^ (l2 >>> 30)) * 0xBF58476D1CE4E5B9L;
1968            l2 = (l2 ^ (l2 >>> 27)) * 0x94D049BB133111EBL;
1969            this.l2 = l2 ^ l2 >>> 31;
1970        }
1971
1972        public Mist(final long alteration1, long alteration2) {
1973            final int i1 = permute(alteration1);
1974            l1 = alteration1 + i1;
1975            l2 = alteration2 + permute(alteration2 + i1);
1976        }
1977
1978        /**
1979         * Makes a new Mist with all of the salt values altered based on the previous salt values.
1980         * This will make a different, incompatible Mist object that will give different results than the original.
1981         * Meant for use in Cuckoo Hashing, which can need the hash function to be updated or changed.
1982         * An alternative is to select a different Mist object from {@link #predefined}, or to simply
1983         * construct a new Mist with a different parameter or set of parameters.
1984         */
1985        @SuppressWarnings("NumericOverflow")
1986        public Mist randomize()
1987        {
1988            long l1, l2;
1989            l1 = this.l2 + permute(this.l2 + 3 * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L);
1990            l1 = (l1 ^ (l1 >>> 30)) * 0xBF58476D1CE4E5B9L;
1991            l1 = (l1 ^ (l1 >>> 27)) * 0x94D049BB133111EBL;
1992            l1 ^= l1 >>> 31;
1993
1994            l2 = permute(l1 + 5 * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) + 6 * 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
1995            l2 = (l2 ^ (l2 >>> 30)) * 0xBF58476D1CE4E5B9L;
1996            l2 = (l2 ^ (l2 >>> 27)) * 0x94D049BB133111EBL;
1997            l2 ^= l2 >>> 31;
1998
1999            return new Mist(l1, l2);
2000        }

2026        public long hash64(final boolean[] data) {
2027            if (data == null)
2028                return 0;
2029            final int len = data.length;
2030            long result = 0x9E3779B97F4A7C94L + l2, a = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L;
2031            for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
2032                result += (a ^= 0x8329C6EB9E6AD3E3L * (data[i] ? 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L : 0x789ABCDEFEDCBA98L)) ^ l2 * a + l1;
2033            }
2034            return result * (a * l1 | 1L) ^ (result << 37 | result >>> 27);
2035        }

2136         * Hashes only a subsection of the given data, starting at start (inclusive), ending before end (exclusive), and
2137         * moving between chars in increments of step (which is always greater than 0).

2139         * @param data  the char array to hash
2140         * @param start the start of the section to hash (inclusive)
2141         * @param end   the end of the section to hash (exclusive)

2143         * @return a 64-bit hash code for the requested section of data
2144         */
2145        public long hash64(final char[] data, final int start, final int end, final int step) {
2146            if (data == null || start >= end || step <= 0)
2147                return 0;
2148            final int len = data.length;
2149            long result = 0x9E3779B97F4A7C94L + l2, a = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L;
2150            for (int i = start; i < end && i < len; i += step) {
2151                result += (a ^= 0x8329C6EB9E6AD3E3L * data[i]) ^ l2 * a + l1;
2152            }
2153            return result * (a * l1 | 1L) ^ (result << 37 | result >>> 27);
2154        }

2408                result += (a ^= 0x8329C6EB9E6AD3E3L * hash64(data[i])) ^ l2 * a + l1;
2409            }
2410            return (int)(result * (a * l1 | 1L) ^ (result << 37 | result >>> 27));
2411        }
2412
2413        public int hash(final Iterable<? extends CharSequence> data) {
2414            if (data == null)
2415                return 0;
2416            long result = 0x9E3779B97F4A7C94L + l2, a = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L;
2417            for (CharSequence datum : data) {
2418                result += (a ^= 0x8329C6EB9E6AD3E3L * hash64(datum)) ^ l2 * a + l1;
2419            }
2420            return (int)(result * (a * l1 | 1L) ^ (result << 37 | result >>> 27));

2434        public int hash(final Object[] data) {
2435            if (data == null)
2436                return 0;
2437            final int len = data.length;
2438            long result = 0x9E3779B97F4A7C94L + l2, a = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L;
2439            Object o;
2440            for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
2441                result += (a ^= 0x8329C6EB9E6AD3E3L * ((o = data[i]) == null ? -1 : o.hashCode())) ^ l2 * a + l1;
2442            }
2443            return (int)(result * (a * l1 | 1L) ^ (result << 37 | result >>> 27));
2444        }

2446        public int hash(final Object data) {
2447            if (data == null)
2448                return 0;
2449            final long a = 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L ^ 0x8329C6EB9E6AD3E3L * data.hashCode(),
2450                    result = 0x9E3779B97F4A7C94L + l2 + (a ^ l2 * a + l1);
2451            return (int)(result * (a * l1 | 1L) ^ (result << 37 | result >>> 27));
2452        }
2453    }
2454
2455    /**
2456     * A reasonably-fast hashing function that passes some of SMHasher's quality tests, but neither critically fails nor
2457     * overwhelmingly succeeds the full SMHasher test battery. This was the default used by methods in the
2458     * outer class like {@link CrossHash#hash(int[])}, but it has been replaced there by {@link Water}; you should
2459     * prefer using the outer class since this inner class is only here for reference. The one advantage Hive has over
2460     * Water is potentially better optimization for GWT, but since the main usage of CrossHash is for 64-bit hashes, GWT
2461     * will be slow regardless for that usage.
2462     * <br>
2463     * This mixes three different algorithms: the main one is used whenever inputs or outputs are 64-bit (so, all
2464     * hash64() overloads and {@link Hive#hash(long[])} for long and double), a modification of the main one to perform
2465     * better on GWT (only used on hash() overloads, and only when inputs are individually 32-bit or less), and
2466     * a simpler algorithm (which was called Jolt) for hash64() on boolean and byte data.
2467     * <br>
2468     * Speed-wise, the main algorithm is about 20% slower than Wisp, but in hash tables it doesn't have clear failure 
2469     * cases like Wisp does on some inputs (such as fixed-length Strings with identical prefixes). If collisions are
2470     * expensive or profiling shows that Wisp's algorithm is colliding at a high rate, you should probably use the
2471     * normal IHasher and CrossHash.hash() methods, since those will use Hive. The modified algorithm for GWT is a
2472     * little slower than the main algorithm in the C++ implementation that was used to check SMHasher quality, but it
2473     * may perform similarly to the main algorithm in Java on desktop platforms. Since it avoids creating longs or doing
2474     * any math on them, it should be at least 3x faster than the main algorithm on GWT (a GWT long is internally
2475     * represented by 3 JS numbers, so barring special optimizations it takes at least 3x as many math operations to use
2476     * longs there).
2477     * <br>
2478     * Its design uses two states like {@link Lightning} or {@link Wisp}, updating them differently from each other, and
2479     * bitwise-rotates one at each step. It combines the states (xorshifting one state, multiplying it by a huge
2480     * constant, and adding that to the other state) and then runs that through MurmurHash3's finalization function (its
2481     * {@code fmix64()} function; the main algorithm elides one xorshift at the end that proved unnecessary). Parts of
2482     * the code here are inspired by the design of {@link DiverRNG}, particularly its determine() method since both
2483     * use an XLCG (XOR Linear Congruential Generator, as PractRand calls it) as a processing step.
2484     * <br>
2485     * The name comes from the song I was listening to when I finally got the tests to pass ("Slave The Hive" by High On
2486     * Fire) and from the wide assortment of code that I had to employ to achieve a SMHasher successful run (which
2487     * turned out to be not-so-successful).
2488     */
2489    public static final class Hive {
2490        public static long hash64(final CharSequence data) {
2491            if (data == null)
2492                return 0L;
2493            long result = 0x1A976FDF6BF60B8EL, z = 0x60642E2A34326F15L;
2494            final int len = data.length();
2495            for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
2496                result ^= (z += (data.charAt(i) ^ 0xC6BC279692B5CC85L) * 0x6C8E9CF570932BABL);
2497                result = (result << 54 | result >>> 10);
2498            }
2499            result += (z ^ z >>> 26) * 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L;
2500            result = (result ^ result >>> 33) * 0xFF51AFD7ED558CCDL;
2501            return ((result ^ result >>> 33) * 0xC4CEB9FE1A85EC53L);
2502        }
2503
2504        public static long hash64(final boolean[] data) {
2505            if (data == null)
2506                return 0L;
2507            long result = 0x1A976FDF6BF60B8EL, z = 0x60642E2A34326F15L;
2508            final int len = data.length;
2509            for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
2510                result ^= (z += (data[i] ? 0xFF51AFD7ED558CCDL : 0xC4CEB9FE1A85EC53L));
2511            }
2512            result += (z ^ z >>> 26) * 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L;
2513            result ^= result >>> 25 ^ z ^ z >>> 29;
2514            result = (result ^ result >>> 33) * 0xFF51AFD7ED558CCDL;
2515            result = (result ^ result >>> 33) * 0xC4CEB9FE1A85EC53L;
2516            return (result ^ result >>> 33);
2517        }

2618        /**
2619         * Hashes only a subsection of the given data, starting at start (inclusive) and ending before end (exclusive).
2620         *
2621         * @param data  the char array to hash
2622         * @param start the start of the section to hash (inclusive)
2623         * @param end   the end of the section to hash (exclusive)
2624         * @return a 32-bit hash code for the requested section of data
2625         */
2626        public static long hash64(final char[] data, final int start, final int end) {
2627            if (data == null || start >= end)
2628                return 0L;
2629            long result = 0x1A976FDF6BF60B8EL, z = 0x60642E2A34326F15L;
2630            final int len = Math.min(end, data.length);
2631            for (int i = start; i < len; i++) {
2632                result ^= (z += (data[i] ^ 0xC6BC279692B5CC85L) * 0x6C8E9CF570932BABL);
2633                result = (result << 54 | result >>> 10);
2634            }
2635            result += (z ^ z >>> 26) * 0x632BE59BD9B4E019L;
2636            result = (result ^ result >>> 33) * 0xFF51AFD7ED558CCDL;
2637            return ((result ^ result >>> 33) * 0xC4CEB9FE1A85EC53L);
2638        }

2678                result ^= (z += (data[i] ^ 0xC6BC279692B5CC85L) * 0x6C8E9CF570932BABL);

2828            result = (result ^ result >>> 33) * 0xC4CEB9FE1A85EC53L;
2829            return (result ^ result >>> 33);
2830        }

3192
3193    /**
3194     * A fairly fast hashing algorithm in general, Water performs especially well on large arrays, and passes SMHasher's
3195     * newest and most stringent version of tests. The int-hashing {@link #hash(int[])} method is almost twice as fast
3196     * as {@link Hive#hash(int[])} and faster than {@link Arrays#hashCode(int[])}; on longer arrays
3197     * {@link Curlup#hash(int[])} is faster. Based on <a href="https://github.com/wangyi-fudan/wyhash">wyhash</a>,
3198     * specifically <a href="https://github.com/tommyettinger/waterhash">the waterhash variant</a>. This version passes
3199     * SMHasher for both the 32-bit output hash() methods and the 64-bit output hash64() methods (which use the slightly
3200     * tweaked wheathash variant in the waterhash Git repo, or woothash for hashing long arrays). While an earlier
3201     * version passed rurban/smhasher, it failed demerphq/smhasher (Yves' more stringent fork), so some minor tweaks
3202     * allowed the latest code to pass Yves' test. Uses 64-bit math, so it won't be as fast on GWT. Currently, the
3203     * methods that hash types other than int arrays aren't as fast as the int array hash, but they are usually faster
3204     * than the former default Hive implementation, and unlike Hive, these pass SMHasher. If you want to have a seed the
3205     * hash, so hashing the same data with a different seed produces different output, you can use {@link Yolk} or
3206     * {@link Curlup}, preferring Curlup unless all of your data is in small arrays (under 20 length, give or take).
3207     * <br>
3208     * These hash functions are so fast because they operate in bulk on 4 items at a time, such as 4 ints (which is the
3209     * optimal case), 4 bytes, or 4 longs (which uses a different algorithm). This bulk operation usually entails 3
3210     * multiplications and some other, cheaper operations per 4 items hashed. For long arrays, it requires many more
3211     * multiplications, but modern CPUs can pipeline the operations on unrelated longs to run in parallel on one core.
3212     * If any items are left over after the bulk segment, Water uses the least effort possible to hash the remaining 1,
3213     * 2, or 3 items left. Most of these operations use the method {@link #mum(long, long)}, which helps take two inputs
3214     * and multiply them once, getting a more-random result after another small step. The long array code uses
3215     * {@link #wow(long, long)} (similar to mum upside-down), which mixes up its arguments with each other before
3216     * multplying. It finishes with either code similar to mum() for 32-bit output hash() methods, or a somewhat more
3217     * rigorous method for 64-bit output hash64() methods (still similar to mum).
3218     */
3219    public static final class Water {
3220        /**
3221         * Big constant 0.
3222         */
3223        public static final long b0 = 0xA0761D6478BD642FL;
3224        /**
3225         * Big constant 1.
3226         */
3227        public static final long b1 = 0xE7037ED1A0B428DBL;
3228        /**
3229         * Big constant 2.
3230         */
3231        public static final long b2 = 0x8EBC6AF09C88C6E3L;
3232        /**
3233         * Big constant 3.
3234         */
3235        public static final long b3 = 0x589965CC75374CC3L;
3236        /**
3237         * Big constant 4.
3238         */
3239        public static final long b4 = 0x1D8E4E27C47D124FL;
3240        /**
3241         * Big constant 5.
3242         */
3243        public static final long b5 = 0xEB44ACCAB455D165L;
3244
3245        /**
3246         * Takes two arguments that are technically longs, and should be very different, and uses them to get a result
3247         * that is technically a long and mixes the bits of the inputs. The arguments and result are only technically
3248         * longs because their lower 32 bits matter much more than their upper 32, and giving just any long won't work.
3249         * <br>
3250         * This is very similar to wyhash's mum function, but doesn't use 128-bit math because it expects that its
3251         * arguments are only relevant in their lower 32 bits (allowing their product to fit in 64 bits).
3252         * @param a a long that should probably only hold an int's worth of data
3253         * @param b a long that should probably only hold an int's worth of data
3254         * @return a sort-of randomized output dependent on both inputs
3255         */
3256        public static long mum(final long a, final long b) {
3257            final long n = a * b;
3258            return n - (n >>> 32);
3259        }
3260
3261        /**
3262         * A slower but higher-quality variant on {@link #mum(long, long)} that can take two arbitrary longs (with any
3263         * of their 64 bits containing relevant data) instead of mum's 32-bit sections of its inputs, and outputs a
3264         * 64-bit result that can have any of its bits used.
3265         * <br>
3266         * This was changed so it distributes bits from both inputs a little better on July 6, 2019.
3267         * @param a any long
3268         * @param b any long
3269         * @return a sort-of randomized output dependent on both inputs
3270         */
3271        public static long wow(final long a, final long b) {
3272            final long n = (a ^ (b << 39 | b >>> 25)) * (b ^ (a << 39 | a >>> 25));
3273            return n ^ (n >>> 32);
3274        }
3275
3276        public static long hash64(final boolean[] data) {
3277            if (data == null) return 0;
3278            long seed = 9069147967908697017L;//seed = b1 ^ b1 >>> 29 ^ b1 >>> 43 ^ b1 << 7 ^ b1 << 53;
3279            final int len = data.length;
3280            for (int i = 3; i < len; i+=4) {
3281                seed = mum(
3282                        mum((data[i-3] ? 0x9E3779B9L : 0x7F4A7C15L) ^ b1, (data[i-2] ? 0x9E3779B9L : 0x7F4A7C15L) ^ b2) + seed,
3283                        mum((data[i-1] ? 0x9E3779B9L : 0x7F4A7C15L) ^ b3, (data[i] ? 0x9E3779B9L : 0x7F4A7C15L) ^ b4));
3284            }
3285            switch (len & 3) {
3286                case 0: seed = mum(b1 ^ seed, b4 + seed); break;
3287                case 1: seed = mum(seed ^ (data[len-1] ? 0x9E37L : 0x7F4AL), b3 ^ (data[len-1]  ? 0x79B9L : 0x7C15L)); break;
3288                case 2: seed = mum(seed ^ (data[len-2] ? 0x9E3779B9L : 0x7F4A7C15L), b0 ^ (data[len-1] ? 0x9E3779B9L : 0x7F4A7C15L)); break;

3407        public static long hash64(final long[] data) {
3408            if (data == null) return 0;
3409//          long seed = b0 ^ b0 >>> 23 ^ b0 >>> 48 ^ b0 << 7 ^ b0 << 53, 
3410//                    a = seed + b4, b = seed + b3,
3411//                    c = seed + b2, d = seed + b1;
3412            long seed = 0x1E98AE18CA351B28L,
3413                    a = 0x3C26FC408EB22D77L, b = 0x773213E53F6C67EBL,
3414                    c = 0xAD55190966BDE20BL, d = 0x59C2CEA6AE94403L;
3415            final int len = data.length;
3416            for (int i = 3; i < len; i+=4) {
3417                a ^= data[i-3] * b1; a = (a << 23 | a >>> 41) * b3;
3418                b ^= data[i-2] * b2; b = (b << 25 | b >>> 39) * b4;
3419                c ^= data[i-1] * b3; c = (c << 29 | c >>> 35) * b5;
3420                d ^= data[i  ] * b4; d = (d << 31 | d >>> 33) * b1;
3421                seed += a + b + c + d;
3422            }
3423            seed += b5;
3424            switch (len & 3) {
3425                case 1: seed = wow(seed, b1 ^ data[len-1]); break;
3426                case 2: seed = wow(seed + data[len-2], b2 + data[len-1]); break;
3427                case 3: seed = wow(seed + data[len-3], b2 + data[len-2]) ^ wow(seed + data[len-1], seed ^ b3); break;
3428            }
3429            seed = (seed ^ seed << 16) * (len ^ b0 ^ seed >>> 32);
3430            return seed - (seed >>> 31) + (seed << 33);
3431        }

3469        /**
3470         * Hashes only a subsection of the given data, starting at start (inclusive) and ending before end (exclusive).
3471         *
3472         * @param data  the char array to hash
3473         * @param start the start of the section to hash (inclusive)
3474         * @param end   the end of the section to hash (exclusive)
3475         * @return a 64-bit hash code for the requested section of data
3476         */
3477        public static long hash64(final char[] data, final int start, final int end) {
3478            if (data == null || start >= end)
3479                return 0;
3480            long seed = 9069147967908697017L;
3481            final int len = Math.min(end, data.length);
3482            for (int i = start + 3; i < len; i+=4) {
3483                seed = mum(
3484                        mum(data[i-3] ^ b1, data[i-2] ^ b2) + seed,
3485                        mum(data[i-1] ^ b3, data[i] ^ b4));
3486            }
3487            switch (len - start & 3) {
3488                case 0: seed = mum(b1 ^ seed, b4 + seed); break;
3489                case 1: seed = mum(seed ^ b3, b4 ^ data[len-1]); break;
3490                case 2: seed = mum(seed ^ data[len-2], b3 ^ data[len-1]); break;
3491                case 3: seed = mum(seed ^ data[len-3] ^ (long) data[len - 2] << 16, b1 ^ data[len-1]); break;
3492            }
3493            return mum(seed ^ seed << 16, len - start ^ b0);
3494        }

3695                        mum((data[i-3] ? 0x9E3779B9L : 0x7F4A7C15L) ^ b1, (data[i-2] ? 0x9E3779B9L : 0x7F4A7C15L) ^ b2) + seed,
3696                        mum((data[i-1] ? 0x9E3779B9L : 0x7F4A7C15L) ^ b3, (data[i] ? 0x9E3779B9L : 0x7F4A7C15L) ^ b4));
3697            }
3698            switch (len & 3) {
3699                case 0: seed = mum(b1 ^ seed, b4 + seed); break;
3700                case 1: seed = mum(seed ^ (data[len-1] ? 0x9E37L : 0x7F4AL), b3 ^ (data[len-1]  ? 0x79B9L : 0x7C15L)); break;
3701                case 2: seed = mum(seed ^ (data[len-2] ? 0x9E3779B9L : 0x7F4A7C15L), b0 ^ (data[len-1] ? 0x9E3779B9L : 0x7F4A7C15L)); break;
3702                case 3: seed = mum(seed ^ (data[len-3] ? 0x9E3779B9L : 0x7F4A7C15L), b2 ^ (data[len-2] ? 0x9E3779B9L : 0x7F4A7C15L)) ^ mum(seed ^ (data[len-1] ? 0x9E3779B9 : 0x7F4A7C15), b4); break;
3703            }
3704            return (int) mum(seed ^ seed << 16, len ^ b0);
3705        }

3811        public static int hash(final long[] data) {
3812            if (data == null) return 0;
3813            //long seed = 0x1E98AE18CA351B28L,// seed = b0 ^ b0 >>> 23 ^ b0 >>> 48 ^ b0 << 7 ^ b0 << 53, 
3814//                    a = seed ^ b4, b = (seed << 17 | seed >>> 47) ^ b3,
3815//                    c = (seed << 31 | seed >>> 33) ^ b2, d = (seed << 47 | seed >>> 17) ^ b1;
3816            //a = 0x316E03F0E480967L, b = 0x4A8F1A6436771F2L,
3817            //        c = 0xEBA6E76493C491EFL, d = 0x6A97719DF7B84DC1L;
3818            long seed = 0x1E98AE18CA351B28L, a = 0x3C26FC408EB22D77L, b = 0x773213E53F6C67EBL, c = 0xAD55190966BDE20BL, d = 0x59C2CEA6AE94403L;
3819            final int len = data.length;
3820            for (int i = 3; i < len; i+=4) {
3821                a ^= data[i-3] * b1; a = (a << 23 | a >>> 41) * b3;
3822                b ^= data[i-2] * b2; b = (b << 25 | b >>> 39) * b4;
3823                c ^= data[i-1] * b3; c = (c << 29 | c >>> 35) * b5;
3824                d ^= data[i  ] * b4; d = (d << 31 | d >>> 33) * b1;
3825                seed += a + b + c + d;
3826            }
3827            seed += b5;
3828            switch (len & 3) {
3829                case 1: seed = wow(seed, b1 ^ data[len-1]); break;
3830                case 2: seed = wow(seed + data[len-2], b2 + data[len-1]); break;
3831                case 3: seed = wow(seed + data[len-3], b2 + data[len-2]) ^ wow(seed + data[len-1], seed ^ b3); break;
3832            }
3833            seed = (seed ^ seed << 16) * (len ^ b0 ^ seed >>> 32);
3834            return (int)(seed - (seed >>> 32));
3835        }

3872        /**
3873         * Hashes only a subsection of the given data, starting at start (inclusive) and ending before end (exclusive).
3874         *
3875         * @param data  the char array to hash
3876         * @param start the start of the section to hash (inclusive)
3877         * @param end   the end of the section to hash (exclusive)
3878         * @return a 32-bit hash code for the requested section of data
3879         */
3880        public static int hash(final char[] data, final int start, final int end) {
3881            if (data == null || start >= end)
3882                return 0;
3883            long seed = -260224914646652572L;//b1 ^ b1 >>> 41 ^ b1 << 53;
3884            final int len = Math.min(end, data.length);
3885            for (int i = start + 3; i < len; i+=4) {
3886                seed = mum(
3887                        mum(data[i-3] ^ b1, data[i-2] ^ b2) + seed,
3888                        mum(data[i-1] ^ b3, data[i] ^ b4));
3889            }
3890            switch (len - start & 3) {
3891                case 0: seed = mum(b1 ^ seed, b4 + seed); break;
3892                case 1: seed = mum(seed ^ b3, b4 ^ data[len-1]); break;
3893                case 2: seed = mum(seed ^ data[len-2], b3 ^ data[len-1]); break;
3894                case 3: seed = mum(seed ^ data[len-3] ^ (long) data[len - 2] << 16, b1 ^ data[len-1]); break;
3895            }
3896            return (int) mum(seed ^ seed << 16, len - start ^ b0);
3897        }

4022        public static int hash(final Iterable<? extends CharSequence> data) {
4023            if (data == null) return 0;
4024            long seed = -260224914646652572L;//b1 ^ b1 >>> 41 ^ b1 << 53;
4025            final Iterator<? extends CharSequence> it = data.iterator();
4026            int len = 0;
4027            while (it.hasNext())
4028            {
4029                ++len;
4030                seed = mum(
4031                        mum(hash(it.next()) ^ b1, (it.hasNext() ? hash(it.next()) ^ b2 ^ ++len : b2)) + seed,
4032                        mum((it.hasNext() ? hash(it.next()) ^ b3 ^ ++len : b3), (it.hasNext() ? hash(it.next()) ^ b4 ^ ++len : b4)));
4033            }
4034            return (int) mum(seed ^ seed << 16, len ^ b0);
4035        }

4075        public static int hash(final Object data) {
4076            if (data == null)
4077                return 0;
4078            final int h = data.hashCode() * 0x9E375;
4079            return h ^ (h >>> 16);
4080        }
4081    }

4083    /**
4084     * Like Mist, this is a class for hash functors, each an object with a 64-bit long seed, but it uses about the same
4085     * algorithm as {@link Water} instead of the older, less-robust style Mist uses. This can be faster than
4086     * {@link Curlup}, but only for small arrays as input (20 length or less); it tends to be slower on larger arrays,
4087     * though not by much, and should be the same for {@code long[]} since they share an implementation for that type.
4088     * Normally you should prefer Curlup if you know some or all of your arrays will be of moderate size or larger.
4089     * Has a lot of predefined functors (192, named after 24 Greek letters and 72 Goetic demons, see
4090     * <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lesser_Key_of_Solomon#The_Seventy-Two_Demons">Wikipedia for the demons</a>,
4091     * in both lower case and lower case with a trailing underscore). You probably want to use {@link #predefined}
4092     * instead of wrangling demon names; you can always choose an element from predefined with a 7-bit number, and there
4093     * are 64 numbers outside that range so you can choose any of those when a functor must be different.
4094     */
4095    public static final class Yolk {
4096        private final long seed;
4097
4098        public Yolk(){
4099            this.seed = 9069147967908697017L;
4100        }
4101        public Yolk(long seed)
4102        {
4103            seed += b1;
4104            this.seed = seed ^ seed >>> 23 ^ seed >>> 48 ^ seed << 7 ^ seed << 53;
4105        }
4106        public Yolk(final CharSequence seed)
4107        {
4108            this(Hive.hash64(seed));
4109        }
4110

4191        public long hash64(final boolean[] data) {
4192            if (data == null) return 0;
4193            long seed = this.seed;//seed = b1 ^ b1 >>> 29 ^ b1 >>> 43 ^ b1 << 7 ^ b1 << 53;
4194            final int len = data.length;
4195            for (int i = 3; i < len; i+=4) {
4196                seed = mum(
4197                        mum((data[i-3] ? 0x9E3779B9L : 0x7F4A7C15L) ^ b1, (data[i-2] ? 0x9E3779B9L : 0x7F4A7C15L) ^ b2) + seed,
4198                        mum((data[i-1] ? 0x9E3779B9L : 0x7F4A7C15L) ^ b3, (data[i] ? 0x9E3779B9L : 0x7F4A7C15L) ^ b4));
4199            }
4200            switch (len & 3) {
4201                case 0: seed = mum(b1 ^ seed, b4 + seed); break;
4202                case 1: seed = mum(seed ^ (data[len-1] ? 0x9E37L : 0x7F4AL), b3 ^ (data[len-1]  ? 0x79B9L : 0x7C15L)); break;
4203                case 2: seed = mum(seed ^ (data[len-2] ? 0x9E3779B9L : 0x7F4A7C15L), b0 ^ (data[len-1] ? 0x9E3779B9L : 0x7F4A7C15L)); break;
4204                case 3: seed = mum(seed ^ (data[len-3] ? 0x9E3779B9L : 0x7F4A7C15L), b2 ^ (data[len-2] ? 0x9E3779B9L : 0x7F4A7C15L)) ^ mum(seed ^ (data[len-1] ? 0x9E3779B9 : 0x7F4A7C15), b4); break;
4205            }
4206            seed = (seed ^ seed << 16) * (len ^ b0);
4207            return seed - (seed >>> 31) + (seed << 33);
4208        }
4209        public long hash64(final byte[] data) {
4210            if (data == null) return 0;
4211            long seed = this.seed;
4212            final int len = data.length;
4213            for (int i = 3; i < len; i+=4) {
4214                seed = mum(
4215                        mum(data[i-3] ^ b1, data[i-2] ^ b2) + seed,
4216                        mum(data[i-1] ^ b3, data[i] ^ b4));
4217            }
4218            switch (len & 3) {
4219                case 0: seed = mum(b1 ^ seed, b4 + seed); break;
4220                case 1: seed = mum(seed ^ b2, b1 ^ data[len-1]); break;
4221                case 2: seed = mum(seed ^ b3, data[len-2] ^ data[len-1] << 8 ^ b4); break;
4222                case 3: seed = mum(seed ^ data[len-3] ^ data[len-2] << 8, b2 ^ data[len-1]); break;
4223            }
4224            seed = (seed ^ seed << 16) * (len ^ b0);
4225            return seed - (seed >>> 31) + (seed << 33);
4226        }

4234                        mum(data[i-3] ^ b1, data[i-2] ^ b2) + seed,
4235                        mum(data[i-1] ^ b3, data[i] ^ b4));
4236            }

4238                case 0: seed = mum(b1 ^ seed, b4 + seed); break;
4239                case 1: seed = mum(seed ^ b3, b4 ^ data[len-1]); break;
4240                case 2: seed = mum(seed ^ data[len-2], b3 ^ data[len-1]); break;
4241                case 3: seed = mum(seed ^ data[len-3] ^ data[len-2] << 16, b1 ^ data[len-1]); break;
4242            }

4244            return seed - (seed >>> 31) + (seed << 33);

4251            for (int i = 3; i < len; i+=4) {
4252                seed = mum(
4253                        mum(data[i-3] ^ b1, data[i-2] ^ b2) + seed,
4254                        mum(data[i-1] ^ b3, data[i] ^ b4));

4257                case 0: seed = mum(b1 ^ seed, b4 + seed); break;

4260                case 3: seed = mum(seed ^ data[len-3] ^ (long) data[len - 2] << 16, b1 ^ data[len-1]); break;

4266        public long hash64(final CharSequence data) {
4267            if (data == null) return 0;
4268            long seed = this.seed;
4269            final int len = data.length();
4270            for (int i = 3; i < len; i+=4) {
4271                seed = mum(
4272                        mum(data.charAt(i-3) ^ b1, data.charAt(i-2) ^ b2) + seed,
4273                        mum(data.charAt(i-1) ^ b3, data.charAt(i  ) ^ b4));
4274            }
4275            switch (len & 3) {
4276                case 0: seed = mum(b1 ^ seed, b4 + seed); break;
4277                case 1: seed = mum(seed ^ b3, b4 ^ data.charAt(len-1)); break;
4278                case 2: seed = mum(seed ^ data.charAt(len-2), b3 ^ data.charAt(len-1)); break;
4279                case 3: seed = mum(seed ^ data.charAt(len-3) ^ (long) data.charAt(len - 2) << 16, b1 ^ data.charAt(len-1)); break;
4280            }
4281            seed = (seed ^ seed << 16) * (len ^ b0);
4282            return seed - (seed >>> 31) + (seed << 33);
4283        }

4285        public long hash64(final int[] data) {
4286            if (data == null) return 0;
4287            long seed = this.seed;
4288            final int len = data.length;
4289            for (int i = 3; i < len; i+=4) {
4290                seed = mum(
4291                        mum(data[i-3] ^ b1, data[i-2] ^ b2) + seed,
4292                        mum(data[i-1] ^ b3, data[i] ^ b4));
4293            }
4294            switch (len & 3) {
4295                case 0: seed = mum(b1 ^ seed, b4 + seed); break;
4296                case 1: seed = mum(seed ^ (data[len-1] >>> 16), b3 ^ (data[len-1] & 0xFFFFL)); break;
4297                case 2: seed = mum(seed ^ data[len-2], b0 ^ data[len-1]); break;
4298                case 3: seed = mum(seed ^ data[len-3], b2 ^ data[len-2]) ^ mum(seed ^ data[len-1], b4); break;
4299            }
4300            seed = (seed ^ seed << 16) * (len ^ b0);
4301            return seed - (seed >>> 31) + (seed << 33);
4302        }

4304        public long hash64(final int[] data, final int length) {
4305            if (data == null) return 0;
4306            long seed = this.seed;
4307            for (int i = 3; i < length; i+=4) {
4308                seed = mum(
4309                        mum(data[i-3] ^ b1, data[i-2] ^ b2) + seed,
4310                        mum(data[i-1] ^ b3, data[i] ^ b4));
4311            }
4312            switch (length & 3) {
4313                case 0: seed = mum(b1 ^ seed, b4 + seed); break;
4314                case 1: seed = mum(seed ^ (data[length-1] >>> 16), b3 ^ (data[length-1] & 0xFFFFL)); break;
4315                case 2: seed = mum(seed ^ data[length-2], b0 ^ data[length-1]); break;
4316                case 3: seed = mum(seed ^ data[length-3], b2 ^ data[length-2]) ^ mum(seed ^ data[length-1], b4); break;
4317            }
4318            seed = (seed ^ seed << 16) * (length ^ b0);
4319            return seed - (seed >>> 31) + (seed << 33);
4320        }
4321
4322        public long hash64(final long[] data) {
4323            if (data == null) return 0;
4324            long seed = this.seed, a = this.seed + b4, b = this.seed + b3, c = this.seed + b2, d = this.seed + b1;
4325            final int len = data.length;
4326            for (int i = 3; i < len; i+=4) {
4327                a ^= data[i-3] * b1; a = (a << 23 | a >>> 41) * b3;
4328                b ^= data[i-2] * b2; b = (b << 25 | b >>> 39) * b4;
4329                c ^= data[i-1] * b3; c = (c << 29 | c >>> 35) * b5;
4330                d ^= data[i  ] * b4; d = (d << 31 | d >>> 33) * b1;
4331                seed += a + b + c + d;
4332            }
4333            seed += b5;
4334            switch (len & 3) {
4335                case 1: seed = wow(seed, b1 ^ data[len-1]); break;
4336                case 2: seed = wow(seed + data[len-2], b2 + data[len-1]); break;
4337                case 3: seed = wow(seed + data[len-3], b2 + data[len-2]) ^ wow(seed + data[len-1], seed ^ b3); break;
4338            }
4339            seed = (seed ^ seed << 16) * (len ^ b0 ^ seed >>> 32);
4340            return seed - (seed >>> 31) + (seed << 33);
4341        }
4342        public long hash64(final float[] data) {
4343            if (data == null) return 0;
4344            long seed = this.seed;
4345            final int len = data.length;
4346            for (int i = 3; i < len; i+=4) {
4347                seed = mum(
4348                        mum(floatToIntBits(data[i-3]) ^ b1, floatToIntBits(data[i-2]) ^ b2) + seed,
4349                        mum(floatToIntBits(data[i-1]) ^ b3, floatToIntBits(data[i]) ^ b4));
4350            }
4351            switch (len & 3) {
4352                case 0: seed = mum(b1 ^ seed, b4 + seed); break;
4353                case 1: seed = mum(seed ^ (floatToIntBits(data[len-1]) >>> 16), b3 ^ (floatToIntBits(data[len-1]) & 0xFFFFL)); break;
4354                case 2: seed = mum(seed ^ floatToIntBits(data[len-2]), b0 ^ floatToIntBits(data[len-1])); break;
4355                case 3: seed = mum(seed ^ floatToIntBits(data[len-3]), b2 ^ floatToIntBits(data[len-2])) ^ mum(seed ^ floatToIntBits(data[len-1]), b4); break;
4356            }
4357            seed = (seed ^ seed << 16) * (len ^ b0);
4358            return seed - (seed >>> 31) + (seed << 33);
4359        }
4360        public long hash64(final double[] data) {
4361            if (data == null) return 0;
4362            long seed = this.seed;
4363            final int len = data.length;
4364            for (int i = 3; i < len; i+=4) {
4365                seed = mum(
4366                        mum(doubleToMixedIntBits(data[i-3]) ^ b1, doubleToMixedIntBits(data[i-2]) ^ b2) + seed,
4367                        mum(doubleToMixedIntBits(data[i-1]) ^ b3, doubleToMixedIntBits(data[i]) ^ b4));
4368            }
4369            switch (len & 3) {
4370                case 0: seed = mum(b1 ^ seed, b4 + seed); break;
4371                case 1: seed = mum(seed ^ (doubleToMixedIntBits(data[len-1]) >>> 16), b3 ^ (doubleToMixedIntBits(data[len-1]) & 0xFFFFL)); break;
4372                case 2: seed = mum(seed ^ doubleToMixedIntBits(data[len-2]), b0 ^ doubleToMixedIntBits(data[len-1])); break;
4373                case 3: seed = mum(seed ^ doubleToMixedIntBits(data[len-3]), b2 ^ doubleToMixedIntBits(data[len-2])) ^ mum(seed ^ doubleToMixedIntBits(data[len-1]), b4); break;
4374            }
4375            seed = (seed ^ seed << 16) * (len ^ b0);
4376            return seed - (seed >>> 31) + (seed << 33);
4377        }
4378
4379        /**
4380         * Hashes only a subsection of the given data, starting at start (inclusive) and ending before end (exclusive).
4381         *
4382         * @param data  the char array to hash
4383         * @param start the start of the section to hash (inclusive)
4384         * @param end   the end of the section to hash (exclusive)
4385         * @return a 64-bit hash code for the requested section of data
4386         */
4387        public long hash64(final char[] data, final int start, final int end) {
4388            if (data == null || start >= end)
4389                return 0;
4390            long seed = this.seed;
4391            final int len = Math.min(end, data.length);
4392            for (int i = start + 3; i < len; i+=4) {
4393                seed = mum(
4394                        mum(data[i-3] ^ b1, data[i-2] ^ b2) + seed,
4395                        mum(data[i-1] ^ b3, data[i] ^ b4));
4396            }
4397            switch (len - start & 3) {
4398                case 0: seed = mum(b1 ^ seed, b4 + seed); break;
4399                case 1: seed = mum(seed ^ b3, b4 ^ data[len-1]); break;
4400                case 2: seed = mum(seed ^ data[len-2], b3 ^ data[len-1]); break;
4401                case 3: seed = mum(seed ^ data[len-3] ^ (long) data[len - 2] << 16, b1 ^ data[len-1]); break;
4402            }
4403            return mum(seed ^ seed << 16, len - start ^ Water.b0);
4404        }

4406        /**
4407         * Hashes only a subsection of the given data, starting at start (inclusive) and ending before end (exclusive).
4408         *
4409         * @param data  the String or other CharSequence to hash
4410         * @param start the start of the section to hash (inclusive)
4411         * @param end   the end of the section to hash (exclusive)
4412         * @return a 64-bit hash code for the requested section of data
4413         */
4414        public long hash64(final CharSequence data, final int start, final int end) {
4415            if (data == null || start >= end)
4416                return 0;
4417            long seed = this.seed;
4418            final int len = Math.min(end, data.length());
4419            for (int i = start + 3; i < len; i+=4) {
4420                seed = mum(
4421                        mum(data.charAt(i-3) ^ b1, data.charAt(i-2) ^ b2) + seed,
4422                        mum(data.charAt(i-1) ^ b3, data.charAt(i) ^ b4));
4423            }
4424            switch (len - start & 3) {
4425                case 0: seed = mum(b1 ^ seed, b4 + seed); break;
4426                case 1: seed = mum(seed ^ b3, b4 ^ data.charAt(len-1)); break;
4427                case 2: seed = mum(seed ^ data.charAt(len-2), b3 ^ data.charAt(len-1)); break;
4428                case 3: seed = mum(seed ^ data.charAt(len-3) ^ (long) data.charAt(len - 2) << 16, b1 ^ data.charAt(len-1)); break;
4429            }
4430            return mum(seed ^ seed << 16, len - start ^ b0);
4431        }

4441                        mum(hash(data[i-1]) ^ b3, hash(data[i  ]) ^ b4));
4442            }
4443            int t;

4534        public long hash64(final Iterable<? extends CharSequence> data) {
4535            if (data == null) return 0;
4536            long seed = this.seed;
4537            final Iterator<? extends CharSequence> it = data.iterator();
4538            int len = 0;
4539            while (it.hasNext())
4540            {
4541                ++len;
4542                seed = mum(
4543                        mum(hash(it.next()) ^ b1, (it.hasNext() ? hash(it.next()) ^ b2 ^ ++len : b2)) + seed,
4544                        mum((it.hasNext() ? hash(it.next()) ^ b3 ^ ++len : b3), (it.hasNext() ? hash(it.next()) ^ b4 ^ ++len : b4)));
4545            }
4546            seed = (seed ^ seed << 16) * (len ^ b0);
4547            return seed - (seed >>> 31) + (seed << 33);
4548        }
